headline: Peach Preserves
description: This peach canning recipe for preserves made with fresh fruit is easy to make with just 3 ingredients and lets you enjoy sweet peaches all year long.

video.description: See how to make simple homemade peach preserves.
video.name: How to Make Peach Preserves

name: Peach Preserves

recipeInstructions.text: Crush 1 cup of chopped peaches in the bottom of a large saucepan. Add remaining peaches and set the pan over medium-low heat. Bring to a low boil and cook until peaches become liquid with a few bits of peach left, about 20 minutes.
Pour cooked peaches into a bowl, then measure 6 cups peaches back into the pan. Add sugar and bring to a boil over medium heat. Gradually stir in dry pectin; boil for 1 minute.

Remove from heat and transfer to hot, sterilized jars. Top with lids and screw rings on tightly. Process in a hot water bath canner for 10 minutes. Let cool, then store on a shelf in a cool, dark place.

review.reviewBody: Delish, only I did not use pectin... only peaches and sugar with a dash of almond flavoring. Popped it right into the fridge and use as jam and ice cream topping.
I loved and I also left pieces of peaches in mine. So good...

üíóI'm very pleased with the results I got using this recipe for my first ever, homemade peach preserves! I used 12 gorgeous, Georgia cling peaches, (purchased from The Peach Truck Tour, which came to Michigan, where I picked them up) that were just ripe, and came out to exactly 6 cups and one teaspoon (for a sample taste!üòã) of peaches, to work with. I did cut the sugar down to roughly half of what the recipe called for, so about 2 to 2-1/4 cups, as my family prefers a slightly tangier-sweet flavor, and after reading some reviews, I thought it might be just a bit too sweet with 4-1/2 cups sugar added. I also had a box of pectin that was only 1.75 ounces, but it did fine. I LOVE the flavor and consistency of these preserves! SOME of the 8 jars I made, will be gifted. (Do I hafta share!?üòÅ)
Only used 2 cups of sugar and sweeten to taste.

I followed the recipe just to see what the results would be. Great taste! Perfect fruit chunks. But pectin should have been added before the sugar. It's thick, but pourable. Please correct the recipe.
Fantastic! first time making peach preserves and people are asking for my recipe~~
Delicious
So simple,no peeling!! And it‚Äôs not just the simplicity I like it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs also delicious‚Ä¶already on 2nd bottle.
I would love to make this recipe but would like the correction of how much water to add. Its not on here.

This is the second time I‚Äôve made this. The first time I cut the sugar in half. This time, because the fruit was so ripe and sweet, I debated whether to add any sugar at all. I ended up adding 1/2 cup of coconut sugar. Still plenty sweet, and very tasty!

As noted by another viewer, if you watch the end of the video the posted recipe calls for 2 1/2 cups of sugar. The recipe turned out great with the 2 1/2 cups of sugar so I would discourage using 4 1/2 cups of sugar.

The peach preserves turned out great! So tasty with lots of peach chunks in the preserves.

Delicious! Love that you don‚Äôt have to peel the peaches‚Äîso much easier this way, plus it gives the preserves a pretty pink hue. I mashed the whole batch as they cooked and then used my immersion blender to pur√©e the peaches a little before adding the sugar and pectin. Finally, adding about a teaspoon of almond extract at the end really pushes these over the top!
I am thrilled to now own jars of peach syrup! Did not set at all
Just made our first batch! We had a bumper crop off of one peach tree this year.
Great recipe. Very simple and tastes great!
This was a very easy reciepe and it turned out amazing. I cooked it a little bit longer but the finished product was great. Love ???
This was a great first time recipe. I added a touch of Allspice.

I made this from peaches from The Peach Truck and half the batch with Stevia and marked them with green dot stickers for my pre-diabetic husband. He loves this recipe! Easy recipe with great results. Leaving the skins on was perfect! Thanks!
We have made this recipe numerous times, and it's always turned out great! My daughter even won first place at the fair several years ago with this recipe! Thanks for sharing!
Did a bit of tweaking, based on other reviewers suggestions. 12 large overripe peaches yielded the 10 needed cups. Cut the sugar to 2 3/4 cup. One package sugar-free pectin.
Very easy to make and smelled awesome .
The recipe was so simple to follow. I just finished mine so I don't have a completed product yet, but once it sets up over night, I will see what happens. It looks great and smells amazing!!
Absolutely the best!
How many half of pints that you made from the 12 peaches

I had 12 to 14 large peaches and it made 5 pints each time. It was runny so I cooked it on med heat for 15 to 20 minutes until it was thicker. In the 2nd and 3rd batches, I didn't measure the peaches out and just poured the sugar into the peaches and it made 5 pints each time. In total I made 3 batches and I cooked the first batch the longest and they set. The 2nd and 3rd batch were not cooked as long and were not as set. Those haven't been opened yet, but my mother opened her jar and said it was good. I used South Carolina ripe peaches and peeled by hand because I had to cut out some bad places. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because it does need to cook longer to make it thicker. This was my first time at making peach preserves. Also, the pectin only comes as 1.75 oz and I also used a 2nd package to add 1 tablespoon extra to each batch. However, my sister said one box would have been sufficient.

I added one navel orange [unpeeled, sliced very thin, slices quartered] to the fruit, maintaining the same 6 cup measurement and ratios going forward. Have made three batches...Did reduce sugar slightly in one batch. Delicious!

Love this recipe! I've been canning for a few years but still consider myself a novice so to find a simple recipe that works every year is wonderful. 

I use fresh lemon juice (squeezed through a sieve) instead of pectin to keep the peaches from turning brown as I'm dicing them, I think it gives it a brighter color. 

I start with 2 cups of sugar and then gradually add it... we don't like it overly sweet. From about 15 large sized peaches I get 9 half pint jars. Great gifts, everyone truly loves it. 

2020 was the third year using this recipe.
Easy recipe, tasty jam!!!

This is the best peach preserves recipe! I modified it by cutting down the sugar and using low sugar pectin. It really is a beautiful pink color. I can‚Äôt make enough to keep friends and family happy.

I had to make a huge change on the amount of peaches. Not only because mine were small, but also because after watching it boil in the pot it never looked to be 6 cups of liquid! This was even after doing 30 peaches. In the end it made 2 cups of liquid so I cut the rest of the ingredients to a little less than half. The end result was 4 eight oz. jelly jars, which is really all I needed anyway! So 5 stars on the flavor, but 1 star on the ratio equals 3 stars and yes I will make it again!

I used only 2 cups of sugar per batch and it is nicely sweet but strong on the peach flavor. I needed about 20 peaches per batch, the equipment of 3 quarts plus a few for good measure. Canned them when I was done. Yum!

I made this as directed. It came perfect I think its important to not get anxious and jar it before its ready. i place a saucer in the freezer before I started. I used the cold saucer to test the gel. When I could put a teaspoon of the preserves and run my finger through it with out the preserves trying to run back on itself, I knew it was ready. I will recommend this recipe to others.
just like eating fresh peaches! next time I may peel the peaches just because its a little weird taste wise.

I made 3 batches of these, but could not get this to firm up. Measured as directed and cooked the recommended time,tastes wonderful, but I lean pour it out of the jars. Can not figure what went wrong. So disappointed
we used 13 peaches and still didn't get 6 cups, but it tasted amazing! We also used only 2 1/2 of sugar. Definitely recommended.

I didn't try this but so far everyone who has, loves it. Luckily I read reviews first, usually I try not to veer off original recipe as is the first time, but I'm glad I did. The recipe doesn't mention it but the reviews do.....NOT NECESSARY T PEEL THE SKINS OFF.. and I reduced the sugar down to 2.5 cups.
 ---- recipe says to measure 6 cups of peaches, but I just used whatever I ended up with, I didn't measure.

The peaches I used weren't quite ripe, after boiling I had to cook for at least double the time (40-45 mins) for the peaches to be tender enough, and during this time I crushed/mashed the peaches.

This recipe made eight 8 oz jars.
I used the 12 peaches as stated and got 4 cups, proportions are poorly stated. glad I had an extra basket on hand. I used 18 peaches. Make sure you don't get cut short of ingredients.

I like this easy recipe. I think the skins add flavor and help thicken the preserves. I did add some cinnamon, cloves, and a pinch of ginger for a little spice. It also taste great without the spices! I had some on a biscuit as soon as it was done. I am waiting to see how it sets up. Fingers are crossed : )

Very easy. I pureed the peaches to get 6 cups since my kids don't like it chunky. Probably because of that, it was too thick so I had to add about 1/2 cup of water to keep it from splashing around the kitchen when it boiled. It turned out very well.

We used 12 peaches and it made right at six (6) cups which filled four (4) pint jars. We used only two (2) cups of sugar. We did three jars with no spices and then added Cinnamon, Allspice and Nutmeg to the last jar. It turned out really good. It didnt make enough to share, but it is good to just make some in the evening with little fuss.
I do not like super sweet preserves or jam so I always cut sugar in half and use low or no sugar pectin

My mom made jam all my life. Now she is in a memory care unit at 94. She would have never left the skin on the peaches. When I read about this I was intrigued. I've just finished batch 1 of 4. This is the best preserves ever. The color is beautiful from yellow peaches and you can't see the skin at all. I would recommend:
1. For multiple batches, just freeze all your peaches after cutting up and putting fruit fresh on them.
2. Make sure you have all equipment ready and organized.
3. DO NOT use as much sugar as the recipe calls for - I used 2 1/2 cups of sugar as many suggested.

I'm making these for Christmas presents. Thank you so much for this fabulous recipe. It takes a lot of work out of an otherwise much more laborious task.
Very easy to make haven't tried it yet
Turned out really good but was a little on the sweet side. Nice consistency, i definitely will make again since I have a peach tree in the back yard, I may cut down on the amount of sugar though.

I didn‚Äôt realize that you didn‚Äôt have to peel the peaches! Consequently, I think, my peaches didn‚Äôt cook down as they should have, and they weren‚Äôt juicy enough. Also, I could tell I wasn‚Äôt going to have 6 cups. When I realized what went wrong, I chopped and cooked 3 more. I should have done 4 more, but at this point I was pretty done with the whole business! I did end up w/3-16 oz. jars, which is what I was aiming for. I followed the suggestions, only used 2 c. of sugar and added 4 1/2 tsp of extra pectin. I think they‚Äôre going to be great!!
Went well, added only 3 1/2 cups sugar, little cinnamon, 1/4 tsp butter, and some lemon juice

I used only a cup of sugar for this recipe and ended up with a lovely, flavourful, not-too-tart jam. 4.5 cups of sugar for this was WAY too much when I first tried it, it was syrup and not a jam. Still, simple easy to follow instructions were appreciated.
I added 3 Tbspoon cinnamon !!

We have peach trees that are very good producers, so I am always looking for good recipes to use my peaches. We made this recipe as a family 2 years ago, and made 65 jars of this peach preserve. It is excellent! We gave it away to teachers, coaches, friends and family members for Christmas (and kept some for ourselves- which we are still eating, but it's almost gone), and we still get compliments. Definitely recommend, and will be making it again from our peach harvest.
I made it with 3 cups of sugar instead of 4.5 , perfect ! Delicious.

I made double the recipe. Reduced the sugar to 7 1/2 cups instead of 9. This worked well and I like it a bit less sweet. Used two packages of Certo. I left the skin on the peaches and they really do disappear. I used twelve cups of finely diced peaches. The product looks lovely and set nicely. It thickened well but is not as thick as jam, more like homemade cranberry sauce. The peaches have stayed evenly distributed throughout the product. It made 13 cups of preserves. This turned out very well. It is delicious! It is great on toast and would be excellent with pork or turkey as well. Looks just like in the photo.
Way too much sugar. I reduced the sugar to 2.5 cups- much better. Also reduced the pectin to 1 packet and cooked for 1 hour to thicken. Came out perfect!
Liked that I didn‚Äôt have to peel the peaches. Next time I might try a recipe with less sugar. Unfortunately you can‚Äôt use less sugar with this type of pectin, or the preserves won‚Äôt set.

Used this recipe because half our box of fresh peaches got partially frozen. It IS delish! I love that I didn't have to take the skin off and it does add to the overall texture of the jam. I will def make this again - whether the peaches are partially frozen or not.

We had an abundance of jalape√±o peppers from our garden this year, so I added one, seeds and all. It's just the right amount of heat for this delicious recipe! Thank you! BTW, I've NEVER made preserves or canned anything. This was easy!
so few ingredients makes this way more affordable. Out of this world tasty. I now wonder why I ever bought store made jellies and jams

I loved this recipe. It was so simple I almost couldn't believe it. I read all about pectin and pros/cons, but in the end I used it and love the recipe as is. The reviews of other "canners" that don't use it, boil and cool 5Xs to thicken the peaches naturally, but I just didn't want to take that much time. Maybe when I have a rainy day I'll give that a try, but for now. This is the one!!!!!

Easy recipe for first time at canning anything. Our boxes of peaches came with 10 fairly large fruit, so we added a mango to cover the 11th and 12th peach. Added 1/2 tsp each of ground cinnamon and nutmeg to the cooking fruit about 10 minutes in. Did four batches to make 96 1/4 cup jars as favors to a wedding rehearsal dinner. Could not be more pleased!
Awesome..used half the sugar as I am diabetic and used the no/low sugar pectin...my first time canning even gave some away to friends and it was a big hit. THANKS
they are wonderful, the only thing I would like to change is to have it a bit thicker, I did add some cinnamon to one batch, that was delicious too.
Abt two peaches per jelly jar size. Good taste
Great way to use all those extra peaches from the trees.

I had 6 pounds of plums, mostly firm green ones. They were a bear to pit! I cooled it and whizzed it in the food processor and then cooked it to 105 degrees C. It made about 14 half pints. I kept half and gave the other half away. Delicious!

I am looking forward to trying this recipe, as I have some peaches left over from canning peach pie filling. The only problem is, I could not find any information in the instructions regarding adjusting the water bath processing time for high altitude. (Maybe I'm just having a "senior moment" and missed the information.) I live in Colorado Springs, Colorado, which is above 6,000 feet. Please let me know ASAP what the adjustment is -- I don't know how long my peaches will last. :) Thank you.
Karen

I loved this easy recipe and the results were better than I'd hoped. I've had my fair share of jam failures. I used about 5 cups of fresh peaches and substituted 2 cups of Splenda sugar blend for the sugar. It reduced a lot and ended up making a little over two pints, which is fine because we aren't big jam eaters. The 20 minute boil seemed to be the key in getting it to set. By the time the sugar blend and the pectin went in, it was nice and gooey. And it tasted just like peach cobbler filling! The next day, it was solid like real jam. Success!! I will definitely try this one again, maybe adding some spices. Thanks!
I added juice and zest of a large lemon and I feel it brightened flavor...

I love this jam I made it exactly as written-it is a soft set jam however I don't like a jam that is too rubbery. For people who think it's too sweet what I found was initially tasting from the pot it just seemed like sugar no peach flavour but after I jarred it and it had mellowed for a week or two and I opened a jar the sweetness of it had mellowed and the peach flavour had bloomed and it was just lovely so just keep that in mind if you decide to follow the advice of reviewers saying to taste your jam and add sugar to your taste as its cooking. Also and someone else may have already said this but sugar quantities affect set and safety in the canning process so if you're going to adjust your sugar make sure you understand the canning process so that you won't end up unintentionally cooking up a batch of botulism.
Runny and too sweet
First time I've made any kind of jam. I reduced the sugar by a bit but it was still too sweet for my taste, though delicious all the same.

Thank you for this recipe. It was my first time making peach preserve and this was a very easy recipe to use. I used about 12 peaches which resulted in a little over 4 cups when cooked. I used fresh squeezed lemon in place of pectin and 2 cups of sugar. I was a little hesitant about using the peels - so I blanched the peaches - but didn't fuss if the skin did not remove easily. It turned out perfectly. It made 5 -6oz jars - I hope they make it through the weekend - it is so good we can't stop eating it!

First time making preserves. Followed another reviewers advice, reducing peaches to 10, and sugar to 2.5 cups, and it is still super sweet. I also made mine a little chunkier, as we will be using it as a topping for vanilla ice cream and cheesecake
I'm not sure what size peaches this calls for but mine did not set. I reheated with more pectin and it is delicious.
Recipe is straight forward and flavorful. I made it twice in the summer and it keeps very well as freezer jam or in sealed jars!
I cut this recipe in half or less, added almond extract, and it was yummy, not to sweet either. Maybe will make again. Babs

So easy and so delicious. I made the preserves recipe as is and then I made a batch where I substituted 1.5 c of brown sugar for the same amount of granulated sugar and added cinnamon and freshly grated nutmeg. Both were wonderful. Thanks for this easy and great recipe!

JAMMIN (hee, hee) 
pun intended.
But seriously, very very good. Made 1/2 as written & 1/2 a spiced version with candied ginger, vanilla paste, cinnamon & cloves. 
A winner either way!
this is a very good, simple, peachy marmalade! wonderful on ice cream or toast.
This is a great recipe to make preserves with skins. I also used 10 cups chopped peaches and 2 1/2 cups sugar. One box pectin and it was plenty firm.
I made two changes to this recipe. First I peeled the peaches mostly because I had already peeled them to can and secondly I reduced the sugar to 3 cups. Turned out perfectly!
fantastic recipe.
This is a keeper!

Made a preserve for the first time ever, based on this recipe and turned out fantastic. But I made some modifications. 1) Added 1 large lemon, in order to guarantee mixture will be acidic and prevent botulism. 2) Only used 3 cups - 3.5 cups of sugar as the recipe is too sweet. 3) Pureed half of the peaches, not 1/4 of them. 4) 2 oz of powdered pectin was IMPOSSIBLE to find in NYC. So I used 1/4 cup of "apple pectin tablets", crushed into a powder. I found this in a vitamin store. 5) Once the peaches are boiling, you can add the lemon, then sugar, then pectin directly into the pot and cook until 1 min after boiling. 6) Recipe wasn't clear on this but you should be stirring non-stop the mixture. You must achieve boiling bubbles while stirring. Also, always add the hot mixture, to heated empty jars or they will crack.

I cut back on sugar to 2 and a half cups that's as sweet as I wanted it. It had a great flavor and the color was was pretty, all that being said I used 1 and a half envelopes of pectin but unfortunately it came out runny and would never set up to bad because it looks and tasted great. If anyone has any ideas how to make this recipe work, I'd love to hear them

I'm in my seventies and have made jams and jellies for years. I've never cared for peach jam because it was too bland. This recipe is flavorful and fragrant. I did add a little fresh ginger and some cinnamon, but it would be fine without.

I'm glad I read the reviews prior to making this recipe. While I love sweet things, I cannot imagine the flavor of this if I would have used 4.5 cups of sugar. Maybe it's because my peaches were Palisade peaches and they were nice and ripe and already sweet. I used 2.5 cups of sugar to the 6 cups of peach liquid. I cut up 24 cups total of peaches, cooked them down with the juice of two small lemons (about 3 ounces), then measured out the 6 cups of peach liquid prior to adding sugar. I got 3 batches of preserves out of this, with the last batch producing 7.5 cups of peach liquid, and then I adjusted the rest of the ingredients to account for the additional liquid. Because I'm in Colorado and at an elevation of almost 4800 feet above sea level, I did cook the preserves for two minutes after adding the pectin, rather than one minute, to account for the higher altitude. I also added one finely chopped, seeded habanero pepper to the last batch at the same time I added the sugar. I got a total of 24 half-pint jars from my peaches. The taste is very good and not too sweet, although my husband thinks it's too sweet. The batch with the habanero came out perfectly. You can taste the heat but it's not too hot.

I used 3 cups of sugar, because I was worried about it being too sweet. It's perfect! I tasted it while putting them in jars and imagined spooning them on homemade pancakes, yum! My peaches were not over ripened, so I had to use my wisk to smash them a little while waiting for them to reduce.
excellent!!!! just less sugar than recipe said.
Followed recipe as written, but only used 2-1/2 cups of sugar instead of the 4-1/2 that was called for. Looks and tastes delicious .
Love this recipe. Peeled my peaches, not a fan of them.

Very simple, and tasty. If you end up with more, or less peaches than 6 cups, the ratio is:
1 cup cooked peaches: 3/4 sugar: 1 tablespoon pectin.

We used mostly under-ripe, hard peaches as instructed in the tips (about 2/3 of all of the peaches were still hard) and it turned out beautifully. Sweet, with just a touch of tart. Set, it reached a thick consistency halfway between cold honey and firm, cuttable jello.
The only changes we made were:
 1) blending the peach chunks since we prefer smooth (I am not sure where some people in the comments are getting "leave the skin on," but we peeled them first)
2) adding Fruit Fresh Produce Protector (1 tsp per cup of cooked peaches, don't include sugar in that measurement, added at the same time as the pectin) It helps prevent the peach mixture from going brown and the extra acid helps the jam set.
Tips:
-The cooking times are from the onset of a boil (meaning the bubbles don't stop or go away when you stir). Don't start the timer at the first sight of a bubble or things will be underdone and not set. This is especially important if you're making a double batch.
-Stir this a lot to prevent the bottom scorching, but stop and do not stir after the sugar+peaches begins to boil.
-Do not increase the temperature to reduce the cook time. It's tempting with large, slow to heat, batches, but don't. You'll get burnt, caramel-y peach jam.
-If you're the specific type, you need to cook the peaches and sugar together to 220 degrees F. The mixtur

I've made this twice now - both times with great results. Like others, I add some cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves, and I cut down a bit on the sugar. Love not having to peel peaches. The only reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is that I think the amount of peaches should be more precise. Peaches come in lots of sizes, so "12" is a bit vague. Today I used 15 because I wasn't sure mine were large enough. Also, step 2 has us pour cooked peaches from their pan into a bowl, then put 6 cups back into the pan and add sugar, etc., but there's no mention of what to do with the remaining peaches from which you took the 6 cups. As it happened for me, I only had about 7 cups of cooked fruit, so I didn't worry about separating 6 cups. All these little discrepancies aside, though, I LOVE the taste, look, and consistency of these preserves and will no doubt make them again.

I had 50 peaches and added 6 cups of Splenda instead of sugar. I'm happy I started with half the sugar then added one more cup.....it's always good to read reviews before you try a new recipe. It turned out fantastic!
This was my very first try at canning and it turned out excellent. I ended up making 2 batches last week.
Take like Grandma's
My first attempt at preserves. I had to cook my peaches a lot longer than 20 mins...probably close to an hour. Still delicious!! I will definitely make this again.
Tried it, liked it. I read the review about the mixture being too sweet-. A few shakes of a salt and a scant of cinnamon cured that. I'd definitely try this recipe again.

This is my second time making this. It has turned out great both times!!! I add just a little bit of cinnamon! (I am sure its still wonderful without it. )Yes, it is sweet but it tastes like summer in a jar!!!

This recipe fills approximately 24-26 4oz Ball jam jars. Used this recipe to make 4oz jam jars as the guest favor at my wedding. Remove RIPE peach skin with the following process: Make a small X at the base of the peach with a paring knife. Dip in boiling water for about 30 seconds to a minute. Dunk hot peaches into a bowl of ice water. Slip off the skins, but be careful now, the naked peaches are slippery. Once all measured peaches are back in the pot along with the sugar, the chunks need to be smashed up according to the consistency of jam you prefer. This is easily done with a potato masher. 
I put a round white sticker on top of the jar lid after sterilizing the jars in a water bath (used my All American Canner, a marvelous canning accessory!) and wrote each guests' name on it. That doubled my guest favor as a place marker for the seating arrangement. My wedding guests loved the gift, got fantastic reviews. One guest used it as an ice cream topping. Others just spread it on toast. 
I made several batches and they varied in consistency, not sure if this was due to not keeping the jam in the hot pot long enough to thicken more or if the ripeness of the peaches (or rather, lack of) influenced the overall result. The only "complaint" I got was that (and mostly only the men said this), "It's too sweet." Otherwise, very good, simple recipe, will use again and again.

This is my first time making any sort of fruit spread, but certainly not my first time cooking. Thank goodness for that--my preserves were turning into nothing like the recipe or the video. They weren't very juicy, and even on low heat, they were trying to burn and caramelize at the bottom before they became liquid. I ended up with a mushy mess (like the consistency of slop) instead of a liquid. And it was a darker brown, which indicated caramelization. 12 peaches yielded 4 1/2 cups of "liquid" peach. 2 cups sugar sweetened it up plenty, and the final yield was 5 1/2-8 ounce jars. Much less than expected, but I'll forgive the recipe because it tasted ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. Just be mindful of your peaches as you cook--not all peaches will cook up exactly the same, and no two batches will be alike. Happy canning! EDIT: I made this same recipe and tried to do the exact same thing again. WAY too sweet, because the peaches actually were a bit overripe. How to save preserves that are too sweet? Lemon juice!
